final_poem:
Rain, rain—your whisper on the pane
is not the sound I thought it would become.
I expected you to fall in one clean stream,
the kind of weather you see drawn, not worn.

But this is different. Each drop strikes lace
across the glass as if remembering
how thin the line between us stands. You trace
your fingers through the quiet I was making.

I like that—how you're not the expected grace,

but something split, arrested, almost caught.
The way a creek runs full when someone's at the gate,
not yet at the house but turning, pulling back,
as if to say: did you want more? Did you?

You taught me how to listen past the fact:
the rain on leaves is not the same as on slate.
On grass it comes as if the ground were fact
and you could land anywhere in its plate.

I'll write about the window, then I won't—
will write instead about the sound you make
when intercepting gutter metal. That's the part
I didn't know—I'd have gone on making

empty rooms and parlor lights left on,
the usual warmth I try to keep around me
like a coat I've buttoned wrong, and wear
anyway, because that's how I keep from being

just air. But you—your real sound teaches
I was building walls against a different storm.

Now I can't stop thinking of the roof
as if it were a skin, taut and alive,
and you were just below it, tapping
with the precise rhythms only weather knows,

as if to say: I'm here. I'm leaving.
Feel me going. Feel how thin

the material is between us—how the house
is not protection but the thing that makes
the noise when you forget to close the door,
when you let the whole damn building hum

with what I'd call longing, except it was rain,
was just rain on a tin roof in the dark,

and all I had was the window seat,
my back against cold glass, the wet sound
pushing through the seams. I held still.
I think that's when I started listening right.
